title: 115_s1072
content:
The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness across the United States, including rural communities and tribal lands. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including housing, family law, income support, criminal defense, and other services deemed necessary by the Secretary. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary may consult with public and private entities to develop partnerships and require periodic reports on legal services provided under such partnerships. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving housing assistance or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Secretary may disregard breaks in assistance or care for which the veteran is not responsible when determining if a veteran has received care for 60 consecutive days. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness. Amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Amends section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code by adjusting funding for fiscal year 2017 to $500,000,000 and extending training entities for provision of supportive services through 2017.

SEC. 7. Requirement for Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness for eligible veterans and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, which required annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans, is repealed.
